note_text:
Indication: Post-intubation tracheal stenosis.
Procedure: Bronchoscopy with balloon dilation (31630).
- LMA airway.
- Stenosis 2-4cm below cords, 76% narrowing.
- CRE balloon: 12mm, 14mm, 16mm x 45s.
- Post-dilation: 12% residual narrowing.
- No complications.
Plan: Extubate. Decadron 8mg. Follow-up 6 wks.

note_text:
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Therapeutic flexible bronchoscopy with serial balloon dilation.
CLINICAL NARRATIVE: The patient, a 58-year-old female with a history of prolonged intubation complicated by sepsis, presented with biphasic stridor. Upon bronchoscopic evaluation, a complex tracheal stenosis with granulation tissue was identified 2-4 cm subglottically. The lumen was compromised by approximately 76%. Therapeutic intervention was pursued using a CRE balloon catheter. Sequential dilations were performed at 12mm, 14mm, and 16mm for 45 seconds each. Post-procedural inspection revealed significant luminal improvement to 12% residual stenosis without mucosal avulsion. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

Diagnosis: Tracheal stenosis (J95.851).

3. Intervention: CRE balloon dilation. Three separate inflations performed (12mm, 14mm, 16mm) to achieve therapeutic patency.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Therapeutic bronchoscopy with balloon dilation.
CLINICAL SUMMARY: Ms. White, a 36-year-old female with a history of tracheostomy, presented with biphasic stridor. Endoscopic examination revealed an eccentric weblike stenosis in the subglottic region, approximately 1-2 cm distal to the vocal cords. The luminal compromise was estimated at 75%. Mechanical dilation was effected using a controlled radial expansion balloon. Sequential dilations to 16mm resulted in restoration of airway patency to approximately 85% of normal caliber. Hemostasis was maintained.

note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT: Bronchoscopic dilation of anastomotic stricture.
INDICATIONS: A 54-year-old male status post bilateral lung transplant presenting with dyspnea and secretions. Imaging confirmed anastomotic narrowing.
PROCEDURE: General anesthesia was induced. The bronchoscope was introduced via an 8.0mm ETT. A circumferential fibrous stricture was visualized at the bronchial anastomosis with 77% luminal compromise. A Hurricane balloon was utilized for graduated dilation up to 10mm. Post-procedural assessment demonstrated marked improvement in luminal caliber to 79% of expected diameter. No significant hemorrhage occurred.

note_text:
OPERATIVE SUMMARY: Bronchoscopic management of GPA-associated airway stenosis.
PATIENT: 48-year-old male with Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis.
FINDINGS: Significant subglottic stenosis (approx. 79%) extending 1.5 cm. The stenosis was weblike in character.
INTERVENTION: Controlled radial expansion balloon dilation was performed sequentially to 14mm. Two inflation cycles were completed. 
OUTCOME: Residual stenosis reduced to approximately 17%. A minor mucosal tear was noted but required no intervention.

PROCEDURE REPORT: Therapeutic bronchoscopy for bronchus intermedius stenosis.
CLINICAL CONTEXT: 73-year-old female with history of prolonged intubation.
FINDINGS: Circumferential stenosis of the bronchus intermedius, 2 cm distal to the carina, with 55% luminal narrowing.
INTERVENTION: Serial balloon dilation utilizing a CRE catheter was performed to a maximum diameter of 10mm. Each inflation was maintained for 60 seconds.
RESULT: Immediate improvement in airway caliber to 74% patency. Minimal mucosal oozing observed.

OPERATIVE NOTE: Management of post-surgical bronchial anastomotic stricture.
PATIENT: 52-year-old male status post RUL sleeve resection.
FINDINGS: Significant circumferential stenosis at the right upper lobe bronchial anastomosis, estimated at 74% narrowing.
PROCEDURE: Under deep sedation, a Hurricane balloon catheter was positioned across the stricture. Serial dilations were performed to a maximum of 9mm. Four inflation cycles were completed.
OUTCOME: Residual stenosis reduced to 28%. Mild mucosal oozing was noted and was self-limited.

PROCEDURE: Bronchoscopic dilation of inflammatory bronchial stenosis.
ETIOLOGY: Sequelae of pulmonary tuberculosis.
FINDINGS: Eccentric stenosis of the left mainstem bronchus, 3 cm distal to the carina, narrowing the lumen by approximately 59%.

OUTCOME: Improved luminal patency with 34% residual narrowing. Procedure well tolerated.

PATIENT: 48-year-old female recently decannulated.

DIAGNOSIS: Tracheal narrowing after trach removal.
PROCEDURE: Scope with balloon expansion.
DETAILS: We found scar tissue in the middle of the windpipe. We used a radial balloon to stretch it open. We cycled through 12, 14, and 16mm. The airway is much wider now. No damage was seen. She is being sent home.

- No bleeding.

note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE: Palliative bronchoscopic dilation for malignant extrinsic compression.
PATIENT: 78-year-old female with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma.
FINDINGS: Extrinsic compression of the proximal left mainstem bronchus due to mediastinal lymphadenopathy, resulting in 63% luminal narrowing. Complex mucosal changes noted.
INTERVENTION: Hurricane balloon dilation was performed at 6mm, 8mm, and 9mm to alleviate obstruction.
OUTCOME: Improvement in luminal patency to approximately 65%. No complications.

Under general anesthesia, the left mainstem bronchus was found to be narrowed by 63% due to lymphadenopathy. A Hurricane balloon was used for dilation at 6mm, 8mm, and 9mm. The airway patency improved to 65%. There were no complications. The patient was admitted for overnight observation.
